abstract.p: John Pucher letter contends America's auto dependence puts us at mercy of oil-producing cartels and jeopardizes our long-run economic and political independence

block.p: Your March 24 Weiskirchen Journal from Germany suggests that Europeans sacrifice mobility to save energy. Although Europeans make only half as many car trips per day, they make four to eight times as many public transit trips as Americans, and four to five times as many walking and bicycling trips. In most European countries, at least half of all trips are by either public transit, walking or bicycling (compared with less than 10 percent here).

Your March 24 Weiskirchen Journal from Germany suggests that Europeans sacrifice mobility to save energy. Although Europeans make only half as many car trips per day, they make four to eight times as many public transit trips as Americans, and four to five times as many walking and bicycling trips. In most European countries, at least half of all trips are by either public transit, walking or bicycling (compared with less than 10 percent here).

Our nation's auto dependence puts us at the mercy of oil-producing cartels and jeopardizes our long-run economic and political independence. It also pollutes our environment, accelerates global warming and robs us of valuable cardiovascular exercise.
JOHN PUCHER New Brunswick, N.J., March 28, 2000
The writer is a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University.
